items.description: Record of measurements of hearing acuity using an audiometer and their clinical interpretation.
Any unspecified point in time or interval event.
Interpretation of a series of audiometric measurements, for purposes of screening assessment. (synthesised)
The audiometry test result which can be recorded per ear or for both ears simultaneously.
Identification of the ear being tested.
The left ear was tested in isolation.
The right ear was tested in isolation.
The stimulus frequency tested.
The stimulus intensity at threshold for the test frequency.
Presentation of a frequency masking stimulus to the non-test ear to more accurately determine hearing thresholds in the test ear.
Masking for bone conduction was applied to the non-test ear.
No masking was used during the test.
Digital representation of the entire result.
Additional narrative about the test results and intepretation not captured in other fields.
The test has been conducted with the patient using a form of auditory assistance, such as a hearing aid or cochlear implant.
The test has been conducted with the patient using a form of auditory assistance, such as a hearing aid or cochlear implant.
The test has been conducted without the patient using any form of auditory assistance, such as a hearing aid or cochlear implant.
Identification of the frequency-specific stimulus used in measuring the hearing threshold. (synthesised)
Identification of the frequency-specific stimulus used in measuring the hearing threshold.
The test stimulus is a tone burst.
The test stimulus is a click.
Identification of the Audiometry test performed.
Details of audiometer used to conduct the test.
The measured frequency/threshold level pair.
Both ears were tested simultaneously in the soundfield.
Interpretation of a series of audiometric measurements, for purposes of screening assessment.
The test was passed, based on screening criteria.
The test was failed, based on screening criteria.
Interpretation of a series of audiometric measurements for purposes of hearing threshold assessment.
The average pure tone threshold according to the specified averaging criteria.
The criteria on which the Pure Tone Average is calculated. The average is based on air conduction thresholds and masked thresholds replace unmasked thresholds when applying the formula.
The pure tone hearing threshold is calculated using 0.5, 1 and 2 kHz.
The pure tone hearing threshold is calculated using 0.5, 1, 2 and 4 kHz.
Identified type of hearing loss for the test ear, based on all measurements.
Hearing loss that is caused by a combination of conductive problems in the the outer and/or middle ear plus sensorineural problems in the cochlear and/or auditory nerve.
Hearing loss that is caused by damage to, or malfunction of, the cochlea or auditory nerve.
Hearing loss caused by blockage or damage in the outer and/or middle ear.
It is not possible to determine the exact type of hearing loss.
Clinical interpretation of all measurements for the test ear.
An interpretation about the symmetry of hearing loss, based on all hearing acuity measurements for both ears.
The hearing loss is symmetrical.
The hearing loss is assymmetrical.
Identification of whether the subject was exposed to a quiet environment for a specified period prior to testing.
The space and conditions in which the audiometric test is administered.
Sound-treated room designed to attenuate nominal outside noise.
Non sound-treated room with minimal background noise.
Non sound-treated room with moderate background noise.
Non sound-treated room with high background noise.
The test stimulus is a frequency modulated tone, commonly known as a 'warble' tone.
The test stimulus is a pure tone.
Identification of parameters specifying a click stimulus.
Time over which the stimulus grows to full amplitude.
Time over which the stimulus depletes to zero amplitude.
Total duration of the click stimulus.
Scale used for acoustic calibration check.
The sound pressure level scale was used.
The hearing level scale was used.
The normal hearing level scale was used.
Protocol used to measure the hearing threshold for pure tone, play and visual reinforcement orientation audiometry only.
The step size (in decibels) of the change in the stimulus intensity.
Step size of one decibel.
Step size of five decibels.
Step size of ten decibels.
Step size of 20 decibels.
The direction of change in the stimulus intensity.
Initial direction of change of the stimulus intesity is descending, followed by ascending.
Initial direction of change of the stimulus intensity is ascending, followed by descending.
Criteria used to determine a screening assessement pass.
Type of stimulus used.
A tone stimulus was used.
A click stimulus was used.
Identification of the hearing threshold level used to determine a screening assessment pass.
Identification of the stimulus frequency used to determine a screening assessment pass.
Presentation of the test stimulus to the test ear.
The indirect transmission of the test stimulus to the inner ear through the atmosphere, via the auditory canal and middle ear structures.
The stimulus is presented via a loudspeaker located one metre away from the subject.
The stimulus is presented via inset earphones.
The stimulus is presented via external earphones.
The direct transmission of the test stimulus to the inner ear via the cranial bones.
The posterior part of the temporal bone, including the mastoid process.
Area of the head bounded by the normal hairline, eyebrows and the temples on either side.
Details of earphones, either insert or external, used to conduct the test.
Masking for air conduction was applied to the non-test ear.
Narrative description of any modfications to the standard methodology required to enable successful completion of the test.
Additional narrative about the protocol for the audiogram not captured in other fields.
Overall clinical interpretation of the measurements and related findings using an audiometer.
No test result is available for the test ear.
Reason why no result is available for the test ear.
Test preceded by a quiet period.
Test not preceded by a quiet period.
An algorithm to predict the amount of speech that is audible to a patient with a specific hearing loss.
Definition of the threshold level used in the test.
The softest level at which a subject responds to a stimulus.
The softest level at which the subject responds to two out of three consecutive threshold runs.
The softest level at which the subject responds to three out of six consecutive threshold runs.
An interpretation about the laterality of hearing loss, based on all hearing acuity measurements for both ears.
Loss of hearing in both ears.
Loss of hearing in one ear.
Narrative description of the reliability of the test results, as determined by the tester.
Frequency
Loudness
Time

The indirect transmission of the test stimulus to the inner ear through the atmosphere, via the auditory canal and middle ear structures. (synthesised)
The direct transmission of the test stimulus to the inner ear via the cranial bones. (synthesised)
The space and conditions in which the audiometric test is administered. (synthesised)
Definition of the threshold level used in the test. (synthesised)
The step size (in decibels) of the change in the stimulus intensity. (synthesised)
The direction of change in the stimulus intensity. (synthesised)
Scale used for acoustic calibration check. (synthesised)
The criteria on which the Pure Tone Average is calculated. The average is based on air conduction thresholds and masked thresholds replace unmasked thresholds when applying the formula. (synthesised)
Type of stimulus used. (synthesised)

details.purpose: To record measurements of hearing acuity using an audiometer and their interpretation by a clinician.
details.use:
Use to record measurements and related findings of hearing acuity for one ear at a time or both ears simultaneously.
Use to record the interpretation of all measurements of hearing acuity for each ear or both ears if tested simultaneously, and an overall interpretation (or audiological diagnosis).
This archetype has been designed to capture hearing threshold measurements for the following tests: - Pure Tone Audiometry; - Play Audiometry; - Auditory Brainstem Response, for threshold determination only; and - Visual Reinforcement Orientation Audiometry.
All of the data elements are recorded using a single method or protocol. If, during the test, any of the protocol parameters need to be modified, then the subsequent part of the test will need to be recorded within a separate instance of the test data, using the updated protocol parameters.
details.misuse:
Not to be used to record other hearing tests. Use other archetypes as appropriate, for example OBSERVATION.tympanogram.
Other audiology tests which capture different results will need to be recorded in separate archetypes, such as: - Behavioural Observation Audiometry (BOA); - Most Comfortable Listening Level (MCL) and Uncomfortable Listening Level (UCL); and - Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) for diagnostic purposes.
